As I’ve been enjoying a month off in between the jobs and subjecting myself to the brain dump of Nassim Taleb’s Skin In The Game I realized there’s one main learning I got both out of the job hunt and my first job:

item.title: How we found and fixed a rare race condition in our session handling - The GitHub Blog
item.description: On March 8, out of an abundance of caution, we logged all users out of GitHub.com. In this post we share technical details of the vulnerability and steps we're taking to ensure it doesn't happen again.

item.title: Who's the Best Engineer You've Worked With?
item.description: I ask this question in every interview I have with someone who has at least as much experience as I do. I ask this when I’m interviewing job candidates and also when I’m the one applying for a new position. I don’t really care about what that engineer’s name is or where they worked. I ask this question because it seems to be unheard of enough that most don’t have a canned response and it consistently spurs insightful conversation.

item.title: Relentlessly give the user what they want – Bryan Kennedy
item.description: I love my Peloton. Mostly it exists as a fancy piece of abstract art in my office, but I occasionally use it for workouts. When I overcome my lazy butt inertia, my experience is that the Peloton almost always wants to do an update.

item.title: MySQL from Below
item.description: When you insert data into a database and run COMMIT you expect things to be there: Atomically, Consistent, Isolated and Durable, like Codd commanded us 40 years ago, but also quickly. There is a surprising amount of sophistication being poured into this, but since I do not want to shame MongoDB and Redis developers in this post, I am not going to talk about that much in this place.

item.title: Almost Everything You Do Causes Almost Everything

item.title: Can we talk about client-side certificates?
item.description: I’m working on improving the means by which API users authenticate with the SourceHut API. Today, I was reading RFC 6749 (OAuth2) for this purpose, and it got me thinking about the original OAuth spec. I recalled vaguely that it had the API clients actually sign every request, and… yep, indeed it does. This also got me thinking: what else signs requests? TLS!

item.title: OpenTelemetry .NET reaches v1.0 | .NET Blog
item.description: As modern application environments are polyglot, distributed, and increasingly complex, observing your application to identify and react to failures has become challenging. In early 2019, two popular instrumentation projects, OpenTracing and OpenCensus, merged to create OpenTelemetry, a new standard for observability telemetry.

item.title: Let there be more biographies of failures
item.description: Let there be more biographies of failures, people who were ignored by the world, whose ideas came before their time, whose great work was left in ruins. The point of biography is to set an example, to teach us how other people did the things we want to do. That might be something grand like live a good life, or it might be something more mundane like manage a small company. Whatever it is, the genre suffers from selection bias. Only the successful get biographies.
item.author: (Henry Oliver)
